central_thesis: The book presents Saint Expedite as a 'folk saint' known for rapid solutions, providing practical methods for connecting with and petitioning him for various needs. It outlines specific offerings, prayers, and ritual actions, integrating elements of traditional folk magic and Hoodoo to invoke his swift aid for practical outcomes.

structure_content.summary: This section introduces Saint Expedite as a 'folk saint' revered for rapid solutions, distinct from officially canonized saints. It details his widespread veneration, particularly in New Orleans, and describes his traditional iconography: a Roman soldier holding a cross with 'HODIE' (today) and crushing a crow with 'CRAS' (tomorrow), symbolizing his defeat of delay. The legend of his misidentification from a shipping crate is shared, alongside an anecdote demonstrating his swift intervention.

This chapter provides practical guidance for setting up and maintaining a shrine dedicated to Saint Expedite. It specifies essential items such as a red cloth, an image or statue of the saint, red and gold candles (preferably seven or nine-day glass-encased), fresh water changed daily, a plate, and a vase. The importance of specific offerings, including pound cake (his favorite), red carnations, frankincense, myrrh, sandalwood, red wine, Roman coins, bread, and occasionally bourbon, is highlighted. Crucially, offerings are made as 'payment' only after a favour is granted, and the practitioner must uphold their end of the bargain. Spreading his name publicly is also noted as a way to gain his favour.

Two primary methods for petitioning Saint Expedite are detailed. The first involves a direct, devotional approach at the shrine: lighting candles, setting out fresh water, reciting the Our Father once and Hail Mary three times, making the sign of the cross, and then kneeling to state a personal petition. The second method involves writing the request and promised offering on brown paper, signing it, folding it, placing it on a heatproof dish, and burning it with a candle (explicitly avoiding matches, due to a Hoodoo taboo regarding sulphur). Instructions for disposing of ashes and perishable offerings are also provided.

This comprehensive section presents several practical spells leveraging Saint Expedite's influence. These include: a 'Saint Expedite Bath' for removing blockages, utilizing offering water and various herbs; an 'Expedite Oil' recipe for anointing candles and talismans; a 'Black Crow Curse Breaker' for reversing and returning curses, incorporating crow feathers and a specific powder blend; an 'Examinee Mojo Hand' for improving exam results; an 'Expedite Talisman' ritual for strengthening one's connection to the saint, involving a consecrated, inscribed wooden cross; a 'Saint Expedite's Lucky Penny' spell for gambling and general good fortune; and a 'Saint Expedite Justice Spell' for righting wrongs, utilizing a prepared bottle and specific offerings.

The book concludes with a nine-day novena dedicated to Saint Expedite. This involves daily lighting of a red candle and reciting a specific sequence of prayers, including the Our Father, Hail Mary, and the particular novena prayers for each day. The practitioner is instructed to mention their desired grace and promise to follow Saint Expedite's example and propagate his devotion. On the final day, any remaining candle is allowed to burn out, and fresh flowers are offered. The novena is presented as a powerful devotional act for receiving benefits.

key_concepts.definition: A 'folk saint' not officially recognized by the Vatican but widely revered, particularly in New Orleans and Latin American folk magic, for providing rapid solutions and swift intervention in urgent matters. His iconography includes a Roman soldier crushing a crow inscribed with 'CRAS' (tomorrow) and holding a cross with 'HODIE' (today).

A revered figure chosen and honored by common people for specific, often practical, needs, whose veneration typically exists outside official ecclesiastical canonization processes. These saints are often integrated into local magical and spiritual traditions.
Latin for 'today', inscribed on the cross held by Saint Expedite, symbolizing his function in bringing immediate results and his rejection of delay or procrastination.
Latin for 'tomorrow', depicted as a crow crushed under Saint Expedite's foot, representing the saint's power to overcome delay, procrastination, and hindrances to rapid action and resolution.

Specific items (e.g., pound cake, red carnations, incense, red wine, Roman coins, bourbon) given to Saint Expedite as a form of 'payment' or reciprocity for his assistance. These are typically presented only after a petition has been granted, emphasizing a contractual relationship.

A dedicated altar or sacred space set up for the veneration of Saint Expedite, typically adorned with his image or statue, red cloth, candles (red or gold), fresh water, and a place for offerings. It serves as the focal point for all workings.
A formal request or prayer directed to Saint Expedite for assistance with a specific problem or desire. Petitions can be spoken directly at the shrine or written on paper and ritualistically burned.

A nine-day series of prayers and devotional acts performed to a saint, intended to solicit special graces, achieve a specific intention, or deepen one's spiritual connection. For Saint Expedite, it involves daily candle lighting and specific prayer recitations.

A traditional charm bag in Hoodoo and folk magic, consecrated with various magical ingredients and prayers, and carried on the person to achieve a specific magical objective, such as success in exams.

An object, typically a consecrated and ritually prepared item (e.g., a cross inscribed with 'HODIE'), imbued with magical power to attract specific influences, provide protection, or enhance one's connection to a spiritual entity like Saint Expedite.

Practitioners of rootwork, a system of African American folk magic and Hoodoo, who often incorporate saint veneration into their practices. Saint Expedite is a favored ally due to his reputation for effective and quick results.

practical_system.description: The practical system detailed in this book is centered on establishing a reciprocal relationship with Saint Expedite, a folk saint known for rapid solutions. This relationship is built through the diligent setup and maintenance of a dedicated shrine, regular communication via prayer and petition, and specific offerings made as 'payment' upon the successful completion of a requested favor. The system emphasizes clear intention, adherence to ritual protocols, and gratitude, integrating elements of Catholic prayers (Our Father, Hail Mary) with folk magical practices (spiritual baths, charm bags, talismans, specific herbal ingredients).

relevant_quotes.text: Expedite is one of a growing number of 'folk saints'. A folk saint is one chosen by the people as opposed to those saints canonised by the Holy Roman church. Folk saints are not recognised by the Vatican but by the people who love them.
Saint Expedite is known as the patron saint of rapid solutions. He is prayed to when a situation needs to be turned around, hurried along or changed.

Expedite is depicted as a handsome Roman soldier wearing traditional uniform, armour and a red cloak. In his right hand he holds a cross upon which are written the word HODIE, the Latin word for 'today', and underfoot he crushes a crow, from whose mouth spouts a ribbon on which the words CRAS CRAS CRAS can be seen â€” cras being Latin for 'tomorrow'. This is symbolic of Expedite destroying Tomorrow in favour of Today.

As a soldier Expedite expects to be paid for his work and it is important to only ask for one thing at a time. The traditional method of payment is to make an offering of pound cake... This is Expedite's favourite offering.
This payment should always be made on completion of a favour granted by Expedite and always make sure to give him fresh flowers.

critical_analysis.relevance: This book is highly relevant within the field of contemporary folk magic, particularly for practitioners of Hoodoo and those interested in syncretic saint veneration. It serves as a practical manual for engaging with Saint Expedite, a figure increasingly popular in modern occultism for his association with swift results. The text bridges historical/iconographic context with actionable magical instructions, making him accessible to a broad audience seeking rapid solutions to practical problems. Its explicit mention of rootworkers and Hoodoo traditions firmly places Expedite within a specific cultural and magical lineage, while also providing a framework for general occultists to integrate saint work into their practice.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The target audience for this book is primarily practitioners of folk magic, Hoodoo, and practical occultism, ranging from beginners to those with some experience in magical workings. It is also suitable for individuals seeking spiritual assistance for urgent matters and those interested in the role of 'folk saints' in magical traditions. The clear, step-by-step instructions and practical focus make it accessible to anyone looking to establish a working relationship with Saint Expedite for tangible results.
